messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Challenges for analytic calculations of the massive three-loop form factors

Paper Abstract: Abstract The calculation of massive three-loop QCD form factors using in particular the large moments method has been successfully applied to quarkonic contributions in [1]. We give a brief review of the different steps of the calculation and report on improvements of our methods that enabled us to push forward the calculations of the gluonic contributions to the form factors.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Two-loop QCD corrections to the heavy quark form-factors: The Vector contributions",
        "Two-loop QCD corrections to the heavy quark form-factors: Axial vector contributions",
        "Two-loop QCD corrections to the heavy quark form-factors:Anomaly contributions",
        "Decays of scalar and pseudoscalar Higgs bosons into fermions: Two-loop QCD corrections to the Higgs-quark-antiquark amplitude",
        "The QCD form factor of heavy quarks at NNLO",
        "Heavy quark form factors at two loops",
        "Analytic results for planar three-loop integrals for massive form factors",
        "Massive three-loop form factor in the planar limit",
        "Heavy Quark Form Factors at Three Loops in the Planar Limit",
        "High energy behaviour of form factors",
        "Asymptotic behavior of the heavy quark form factors at higher order",
        "Three-loop massive form factors: complete light-fermion corrections for the vector current",
        "Three-loop massive form factors: complete light-fermion and large-Nc corrections for vector, axial-vector, scalar and pseudo-scalar currents",
        "Harmonic polylogarithms",
        "The Heavy Fermion Contributions to the Massive Three Loop Form Factors",
        "Singlet and nonsinglet three-loop massive form factors",
        "Massive Vector Form Factors to Three Loops",
        "Massive three-loop form factors: anomaly contribution",
        "The Method of Arbitrarily Large Moments to Calculate Single Scale Processes in Quantum Field Theory",
        "Automated Solution of First Order Factorizable Systems of Differential Equations in One Variable",
        "Algorithms to solve coupled systems of differential equations in terms of power series",
        "The unpolarized and polarized single-mass three-loop heavy flavor operator matrix elements Ag​g,Q and Δ​Ag​g,Q",
        "The first–order factorizable contributions to the three–loop massive operator matrix elements AQg(3) and ΔAQg(3)",
        "The non-first-order-factorizable contributions to the three-loop single-mass operator matrix elements AQ​g(3) and Δ​AQ​g(3)",
        "The massless three-loop Wilson coefficients for the deep-inelastic structure functions F2, FL, xF3 and g1",
        "The three-loop unpolarized and polarized non-singlet anomalous dimensions from off shell operator matrix elements",
        "Determining the closed forms of the O​(αs3) anomalous dimensions and Wilson coefficients from Mellin moments by means of computer algebra",
        "Automatic Feynman graph generation",
        "New features of FORM",
        "The Multithreaded version of FORM",
        "Group theory factors for Feynman diagrams",
        "The Crusher algorithm",
        "Harmonic Sums and Polylogarithms Generated by Cyclotomic Polynomials",
        "Harmonic sums, Mellin transforms and integrals",
        "Harmonic sums and Mellin transforms up to two loop order",
        "Analytic and Algorithmic Aspects of Generalized Harmonic Sums and Polylogarithms",
        "Iterated Binomial Sums and their Associated Iterated Integrals",
        "Algebraic relations between harmonic sums and associated quantities",
        "Computer Algebra Algorithms for Special Functions in Particle Physics",
        "The package HarmonicSums: Computer Algebra and Analytic aspects of Nested Sums",
        "Uncoupling systems of linear Ore operator equations",
        "Iterated Elliptic and Hypergeometric Integrals for Feynman Diagrams",
        "Ore Polynomials in Sage",
        "Symbolic Summation Assists Combinatorics",
        "Refined telescoping algorithms in R​Π​Σ-extensions to reduce the degrees of the denominators",
        "On Rational and Hypergeometric Solutions of Linear Ordinary Difference Equations in Π​Σ∗-field extensions",
        "Generalization of the Euclidean algorithm for real numbers to all dimensions higher than two",
        "Parallel integer relation detection: Techniques and applications",
        "Integration by parts: The algorithm to calculate beta functions in 4 loops",
        "High precision calculation of multiloop Feynman integrals by difference equations",
        "The SAGEX Review on Scattering Amplitudes, Chapter 4: Multi-loop Feynman Integrals",
        "A Symbolic Summation Approach to Feynman Integral Calculus",
        "Modern computer algebra",
        "The concrete tetrahedron"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Challenges for analytic calculations of the massive three-loop form factors, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
